pros: BP treats its employees really well.  Hours tend to be flexible, benefits are top class, work culture tends to be driven but relaxed.
cons: College graduates may find an eventual glass ceiling if looking for the management track.  Many college recruits tend to leave BP after 7 to 10 years because they find BP tends to have an age bias when promoting staff to the next level of management.  Like most major oil companies, the work force tends to be dominated by Contractors.  There can be an us against them mentality depending on where you work in the company.

review_title: Horrible culture, full of biased ignorant people
pros: No pros of any sorts. they destroy people lungs and planet earth all together.
cons: I cannot wait to delete this company from my CV.  They even collaborate with Princeton University for lobby against alternatives and for spreading fake research to make their business look better. I am ashamed for having worked there. The incentives encourage people to work in silo and get competitive unnecessarily. The ethics and compliance department in London is full of people of religious bias (Muslims and people coming from / and previously educated in countries with no respect for human rights) and they investigate and fire people lacking  any trace of neutrality or respect for the democratic culture they live in.. All people do is gossip and sack each other. It is a hierarchical company where people praise the boss and spits on everyone else. The Upstream sustainability group is led by a person with no moral values and no ethical base. The Downstream sustainability group doesnt exist.  There is no career progress unless you pull the right strings. Avoid this company

review_title: Would be great if only there was some consistency.
pros:
Great team in store.
Progression (at least to DSM level).
Discount. 15% plus 50% on lunch on shift. 
Excellent training programmes, as long as you put in the effort.
Great safety culture, more than just a token gesture. 
Honest hard work, but not difficult.
cons:
Lack of clear distinction/accountabilities between management roles.
Lack of consistent support from Area Management.
No reward/recognition of long service.
Evident gender disparity at Store Manager level. 
Poor Night Premium for CSAs.
Long, long hours for managers with no oppurtunity to receive the time in lieu owed and no overtime allowed for salaried employees.
Stalled progression at DSM level, unless you are male.

review_title: Lots of opportunities and career options
pros:
Strong values, leaders try hard to live the values after some tough years
Travel opportunities were tremendous, very generous, enabled greater effectiveness in the roles
Treats employees right in terms of support and short term decision making
Some of the best years and best memories in my career spent with this company
cons:
Salary limitations eventually catch up if not based in London at some point 
Career progress heavily depends on relationships and who you know, instead of what you know
Leaders with poor reputations are tolerated, rarely sidelined
'Reward' promotions given to some persons who have performed well in a particular area, but don't know much about the area they are given large responsibility for;  keep people working in the areas of their capability and expertise.

pros: I hear many a time when colleagues have left for more money that they actually regret leaving.  the package at BP needs to be looked at as  a total reward package that consists of basic pay which is competitive, benefits that consist of  annual cash bonus, flexible allowance - including car allowance for certain levels and also the experience at work and being able to do meaningful work in a FTSE 100 company which is at the forefront of the oil industry. Comparing BP to other companies BP is like the mother who cares and ensures you are looked after, it may not be the way you want to be looked after but none-the less well looked after.
cons: Change is too frequent, every year we amend the way we work and priorities are always shifting, its the nature of the volatile oil markets. You need to be adaptable to survive and progress. Progress and development feels slow.

review_title: BP is not what their new colors and commercials appear to be.
pros: It was a semi easy retail position. This position had its ups and downs, the customers could be great on a good day. When there was a good team present, things could ge accomplished on that particular site. Management changed often, but some mangement team members were assets to the team.
cons: The politics factor. The PR crap that expect us to project to the customers. Employees were expected to avoid answering questions on the Texas refinery explosion, gas pricing, canopy collapses, and stolen credit card number questions. The usage of secret shoppers and constant new policies are a down fall, when they were unfairly used. Managment would play favorites and the lack of video and audio in managment offices made it hard to prove a case involving management, but they were sure to use these tools when employees were video taped 24/7. Phone call monitoring is also tracked. When we experienced the new internet time clock and automated points system, it was time to go.

review_title: A British Company trying to be an American company doing business in the USA.
pros: They let people pursue their outside passions. Individuals can participate in professional organizations if they choose, However, this is not necessary and more often tahn not managament simply pays no attention to those employees that have managed to find their way into relationships that can be influential in state and federal government. There are a number of very competent personnel as individual contributors. These professionals are very willing to share their knowledge and provide mentoring. Mostly though, these folks do their job and go home never pausing to look back as they await a buy-out package or retirement.
cons: One must stay inside the context of one's job, follow orders and let the Brit's run the outfit. You'll survive and collect a paycheck. Upward feedback is an exercise as the overall culture and morale never seems to change much from year to year. Creativity is not necessary; it is expected that one will stick to their knitting and get their work done.

pros: Great place for a newcomer or a relatively recent undergrad - lots of training opportunities, lots of development opportunities, and all around access to solid corporate best practices to learn all the things one shouldn't do and how to do things well. As a large firm, it does spend its resources and money on developing people and all in all, it is a great starting point for ones career...
cons: After about 10 years or so, even as a high-potential candidate, one often runs into lack of development opportunities, mismatch with salary expectations, lack of opportunities, lack of flexibility (work hours, work locations). In recent years, there has been an outflow of senior level female leaders from the company - see some of the reasons above.

review_title: Global business services at BP is not a place to grow
pros: great benefits: 401k (3% match) , amazing HMO health care (starting at $200 for a couple), 5 days EXPTO, base 2 weeks vacation, holidays off,  2 personal choice holidays (extra 2 days vacation), work from home (1-2 days per week)
cons: At BP, there are constantly too many business and organizational changes, cost cutting left and right (moving work to Accenture in India and Malaysia), divesting businesses just to bring them back after realizing too late they make money, mediocre holiday party to save money, rare spot bonus opportunities, no holiday outing, no team lunches. If you are wanting a career at BP, start at big BP (benefits and pay are much better), rather than BP's Shared Business Services (Global Business Services, GBS). GBS moves work overseas to save money, but does not make the effort to bring more work from BP to supplement the divested activities.

review_title: Worn down, bled dry and used to the last!
pros: Good opportunities for progression from Customer Assistant Level through to Store Management. Fast day and great if you like to be kept constantly busy. Monthly scheme for all CSA to accumulate up £5 (pm) in high street vouchers which can be saved up or cashed in each year.
cons: Terrible pay across all store positions. A very busy and high demanding day for no thanks and no reward. Salaried 40hrs however an average of 50+ is the reality. Bonus structure is constantly changing from year to year making it increasing difficult to acheive targets. very little support from area managemnt mainly because they are too few and their patches are too large. Bank holidays are rolled into management holiday entitlement, meaning Christmas day,boxing day and new years day can all be worked for a measley "day in leui"

review_title: Not the company it once was
pros: BP is a large company, and tries to be one with good values. In the past BP was a company where a strong meritocracy culture prevailed. However, its strength was its weakness, which means a lack of strong business processes allowed for employee room to create as you figured things out. Some would argue this is why we had so many industrial accidents.
cons: Following Macondo, it has become more of "do the right thing for BP" instead of "do the right thing" -- its a subtle but important change. Combine this with weak business processes, and you can imagine the slippery slope when less scrupulous managers acquire power. This is important to understand if you are thinking of entering an employment relationship with BP.

job_title: Materials and Welding Engineer in Katy, TX
pros: Fairly relaxed, flexible hours, 9/80 schedule, easy to convince others that you are an expert in a particular area or product.
cons: Company is in a constant state of flux and reorganization.  Project Management side of the business wants to make change in culture but doesn't follow through on supporting other segments of the organization (engineering in particular).  Even though there have been quite a few layoffs seems most of the folks let go were the productive people and an overwhelming amount of dead weight is still around.  The company management structure is more like office space with no clear directive on a day to day which makes it tough to make progress on anything.

pros: BP allows for its interns to take part in projects that have a large impact to the company's performance. They allow for travel, training, and networking with suppliers. The expirience i have gained working at BP is the best experience I could have ever gotten. I truly know what it is like to be a full time employee working at BP.
cons: As an intern I worked on a very large project. My only issue was that the size and scope was too large to move very fast. I only had 3 months to work on the project and while I gain amazing experience, I wish I could have stayed for some kind of results. The other issue is that your project will vary based on where you were placed. I know my project was amazing but there are others that were not as exciting.

pros: Great benefits and nice amentities such as starbucks coffee and cafeterias in the various buildings as well as a nice gym and medical/pharmacy building for basic needs.
cons: Unfortuatly, the amenities can not over shadow the low moral and poor atmoshpere that soon became a part of the company with the change of management and roles of those within the U.S. Communications Team and C&EA group.  It felt more like a high school popularity contest than work.  Unfortunately, the latter treatment is what has left a very bad taste in my mouth for this company and especially for the U.S. Communications team.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Houston, TX
pros:
* Outstanding pay and benefits
* 9/80's for those who work in the business
* Technical folks are outstanding
cons:
* HR Leadership is very poor
* No 9/80's for Corporate HR --- it is enforced by some departments and not others.  BP proclaims to be 'inclusive' but this is not an inclusive practice
* Takes forever to fire incompetent people

review_title: Only a place to work if you don't have strong ties to your home
pros:
-You work on a two week, rotating schedule, so you get two weeks off at a time
-No real dress code
-Some leeway in how you approach daily tasks
cons:
-You're away from home more than half the year when you factor in travel time
-BP does not cover flights from your home city to Anchorage (though the flight from Anchorage to Prudhoe Bay is covered), so you're stuck paying for that out of pocket, meaning your actual salary drops significantly once that's factored in
-BP is extremely unorganized, and as a company, has no idea on how to run an effective business
-Management is kind of a joke
-Lots of "busy work" which serves no real purpose
-Salaries are not reviewed annually, as they should be

review_title: Good and Bad about working at BP
pros: Good Benefits, reasonable compensation,  flexibility in managing your career, focus on training employees - the company spends a lot of money on learning courses and pays for external training and there is a training budget. There are also many good in-house training to attend.
cons: Reorganization always every two to four years.  The org. structure is always changing do to political battles at the top - the bottom guys have to live with the decisions - good or bad.  Usually the guys at the top move to better job and pay as result of the new design, but the consequences of negative fall-out are felt through the organization at the mid-to-lower level.

review_title: BP Management Framework needs "teeth" - and harsh consequences if not adhered to. Get rid of CIO before it's too late.
pros: It has so many faults, that one can make a difference - if one can influence the senior leadership.
cons: Constant changes / restructures, lack of competent leaders (especially in IT&S), no "teeth" in policies means due process is often ignored with no penalty for the perpetrators, lack of structure in financial authorities / accountabilities. New CIO appears clueless, makes knee-jerk, misinformed decisions....GM all over again!

job_title: Office Administrator in Abu Dhabi, Abu Dhabi
pros: Salary and benefits. This is what tempted me from my old job in the first place, they pay you triple the amount of anyone else and pay for lunch and transportation and phones etc so that all you have to do is pocket your salary at the end of the month.
cons:
The staff and the politics are shocking to say the least. The issues of race and stress increases infinitely the lower down the hierarchy you are. I was on call 24 hours a day and if we had colleagues that came from abroad and got drunk, they would call me at 1 am just to call them a cab and they were at a hotel so this was redundant.

When they wanted to let me go they were so unprofessional. For weeks before that they had meetings with recruitment companies and told me about it. They had meetings about me without me. When we finally had the talk I just said ok and how long is my notice etc, my boss actually asked me if I understood what was going on? The timing of the question was odd.

review_title: Process Operator at BP - Whiting, Indiana
pros: Able to learn the process, use your knowledge and experience to achieve your goals.  I like that we are given authority of our unit and I am able to do my duties without constant watch or second guessing.  Teamwork is great and so are the people.  Great pay and benefits.
cons: Management slow to make decisions.  BP tends to be reactive instead of proactive.  The powers to be make costly and sometimes ill advised decisions in order to appease the safety board.  The COW program (control of work) is ineffective, out of control, and should be abolished or simplified.  More paper, forms, and meetings do not make you work safer or smarter!  Also, BP has too many levels of management and so many made up titles.  With this culture, nobody can make a decision without checking with multi parties involved...... Frustrating sometimes!

review_title: Wonderful town to work in, occasionally frustrating company
pros: As a cashier at this BP convenience store for nearly 7 years, it was a pleasure to meet so many people in a small town with a very welcoming community. The job was enjoyable and a great way to start my working career in high school. Started at minimum wage and, within 3 years, I reached the hourly rate cap for cashiers. Hours are incredibly flexible and the manager really wants you to be successful, considering this is the first job for some high school students in the area.
cons: Although the job isn't physically exhausting, it can be mentally taxing. As with most customer service jobs, some customers can get frustrated easily and may not have patience for a new employee or during a "rush" hour. The register technology at this location is almost 20 years old and, admittedly, has been falling apart over the last year. This problem has caused long closures and many headaches for the management and other employees. Hopefully, the company will soon replace the registers with a more up-to-date system.

review_title: Deepwater Gulf of Mexico Business Unit
pros:
excellent salary and benefits
some truly knowledgable experts to work with
state of art technology
cons:
only 5 options (time frame based) on 401K direction
Utter and appalling disrespect by management towards employees has led to discouragement and low morale.
Management is by quarter; this means necessary long-term expenditures (read maintenance, inspection, etc.) may be deferred.
Focus on personal safety with ignorance about process safety
Wonderful, people-oriented American managers have been replaced with uncaring Brits
Do not seek employment here if you are female or a minority - you will not receive respect or opportunities 
Say no and you will be asked to leave; it is viewed as disrespecting authority;  even politically correct questioning may lead to consequences

review_title: BP is so cheap, doesn't put it's money where its mouth is
pros:
Reasonably intelligent peers, have to be to have survived
You can take on more work and additional responsibilities any time you want
Open networking policy
cons:
They will find a solution that requires no cost, which means talking more about everything and checking and rechecking everything over and over again, and making existing staff do more work.
Senior levels get where they are by designing hatchet type restructurings.  
The old guard didn't do anything well, so everything needs fixing.
BP will not invest money in training or technology.  All training is by internal employees who are unqualified to do so.
They take no chances.
The successful manager must: love BP, love meetings, never speak their mind, never disagree, talk a lot of nonsense, stroke superiors, give average reviews and make subordinates feel expendable and lucky to have a job.   
No raises.  
Your job is to make yourself replaceable, doing so may keep you employed another year if you are lucky.

pros: Great company that wants to train you to be a better employee.  Good benefits and great pay, I make more than my peers at Exxon and Chevron!  My current boss is great and isn't to worried about the time clock as long as you get all your work done. My last boss was a huge dick that didn't portray BP's image at all...  My boss before him was great though so it can be hit or miss.
cons: Sometimes you get stuck working for a raging lunatic and there isn't much you can do about it. Lots of bureaucracy and lots of "process" even if it doesn't make any sense.

review_title: BP is unable to keep their word with jobs and promotions
pros: Pay and benefits are decent...wish there was more I could say, but I feel like just another number.  Look out for your own best interests because they don’t care
cons:
Full of broken promises.  Came to the company in a training program and was promised a promotion upon completion of the program.  That never happened, and I was moved into a role I didn’t join the company for.  After working diligently at that (without ever getting the technical training I was supposed to get), I applied for a role elsewhere in the company.  Went thru the interview process and was selected.  Began negotiations, where the job level was dropped but I was still willing to take it, and then the job was eliminated altogether.  

Just highly disappointed.  You always see the BP safety commercials on TV, and they want you to think they do the right thing.  But by their people, you are just another number.

pros: Nice buildings, campus is Eco-friendly, very convenient work locale, free parking, events for family, good pay and bonuses.
cons: VERY political company, minimal respect for experienced employees joining the company, often times promotions or Senior Level Leader jobs (Level F and above) are only given to people who "know" the management team or who are telling the management team what they want to hear. Very British-centric for adopting ideas and valuing opinions. Americans on global teams are treated with an inferior positioning to their British colleagues. If you can accept this environment then BP is a good fit. Company is downsizing considerably due to the legal problems of the Macondo spill. Basically going to a skeleton work model for the US locations. In financial hardships right now.

review_title: Good place only if you want to do nothing and plan retirement
pros: fitness center on facility is great.  Decent pay for Houston (industry average).
cons: Terrible place for engineers in the beginning of their career (0 - 5 years). No engineering or real work done. Most employees are pushing paperwork and project scheduling. People that remain are milking pension and looking for retirement, or are content doing nothing new for the rest of their career. Extremely bureaucratic and incompetent managers talk about the buzzwords like data science, renewables, Agile, impact-from-day-one, and engineering but have little understanding of what these actually mean and lack the technical foundation. Very little vacation (even with the new policy) and expensive cafeteria.

review_title: If you believe in work ethics, run. don't look back; run away from BP
job_title: Senior Supply Chain Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Great gyms, restaurants, common areas, gardens.   They really splurged on the non-work element of the job.
cons:
After the Macondo disaster, they decided to hire a lot of very qualified people to fix their supplier contract problems, Supplier quality, on-time delivery, improving KPIs and other metrics of performance, etc.

It was all a huge facade.   At the end of the day, they ground down these highly qualified new hires with red-tape, bureaucracy, and the worst inefficiency.  All they really wanted was to look good if they were audited.  Not to really fix any of the structural problems that caused the Gulf of Mexico catastrophe to begin with.

A lot of copy-and-paste in Excel. a lot of BS KPIs, when category managers have no access to on-time-delivery or to Quality from suppliers.  They don't even approve a trip to Lousiana from Houston, for god sakes!

If you want to be well paid and look the other way, this is the place for you.  If you rock the boat, they will make your life a living hell and drive you out.

job_title: Operations Support Manager in London, England
pros:
- The people are really good to work with. 
- The pay and benefits are good. 
- The Company cares a lot about training, ergonomics etc.
- Career progression can be good if you're in with the right people.
cons:
- Some Vendors are a nightmare to work with. Very much focussed on delivering the bare minimum they can get away with. 
- The Company is undergoing constant change due to the numerous Consultancies that come in and fiddle with things but the underlying bureaucracy never changes or gets worse.
- Once you're in you have to stay in each role for 2 years.
- Some people are put in at a lower grade than they should be. It can take a long time to move up to the next one so negotiate!! 
- No women were on the Leadership Team in my department and no women are on the Board..

review_title: Feeling trapped, will jump out in the next available opportunity
pros:
Senior Leadership of the business unit have excellent leadership skills. Great place to hone leadership skills by emulating them.
Good place to learn about the industry
Good work life balance.
cons:
Highly political.
People who have never worked elsewhere have a very narrow minded approach, highly resistant to innovation, new ideas.
Political contacts are more important for promotions, appraisals.
Doesn't feel like a place where one can grow if they are not part of the right political group.
Heard many cases wherein someone in the middle management got pissed off when a newcomer dared to voice his opinion in a meeting, sometimes the manager has even declared - "I will not forgive you for this".
Demotivating for men with the overemphasis placed on promoting and developing women managers.

pros: BP is a company that champions diversity and inclusion. If you are a very high performance employee, you may find promotions come easily. It is a fast paced company where there are many opportunities to challenge yourself. The commitment of employees to work safely is unparalleled.
cons: The expectations of management are not always realistic. This very often leads to an unsustainable work load, sometimes with less that desirable outcomes. While attempts to develop a safety culture are done with good intentions, the methods to achieve safety are typically personnel intensive processes, without the addition of the required  (trained) personnel to carry out the process. The net result is typically not positive.

review_title: Grateful for a launch of a successful career with many opportunities for development, travel, and training
pros: The company is fast moving, not afraid of challenge or to redefine itself; the company culture is open, conscientious, friendly, meritocratic, with a clear internal promotion mechanism and a strong bias towards performance, safety, operational excellence, and strong technical/engineering skill set. The key to success is willingness to work hard, international mobility, and ability to get along with everyone from peers to senior management and the front line employees.
cons: Often too dependent on individual executive agendas, overly ambitious, tolerating behaviours and practices inconsistent with company values, unable to retain top talent in times of crisis or transition.

review_title: A god place to work if you can keep dodging the redundancy rounds
pros: In the past has offered equal opportunities for stimulating jobs, that are well paid, and in pleasant environments, with opportunity to change jobs, train in new skills,
cons: Job security is poor.  In a down turn they let loyal, high performing staff go in large numbers with little chance to argue a case.  Its hard for those who go and also hard for those who stay who have to watch their backs, and keep the work  going and see friends and colleagues let go.

review_title: Good place to work, needs to maintain the watering hole
pros:
- overall excellent, intelligent and competent leadership
- the BP core expected behaviors 
- some work/life balance flexibility such as remote working and flex time. Focus is on delivery and not face time.
cons:
- If you are under 40, the health insurance cost is high due to the higher risk pool at BP 
- While you own your own career, it is difficult finding true and genuine mentorship within the company.  
- Oil and gas industry - the male/female dynamics continue to be a bit of a challenge (unconscious bias).

review_title: Very big, pretty good, under appreciated exploration staff
pros:
BP has a top notch portfolio with one of the best records of reserves replacment.  Training is excellent and consideration for flexibility in life issues is above average.  

The wild-cat wells are often genuinly wild-cats.
cons:
I think technical staff are somewhat under appreciated in that there's a strong push to reduce promotions so as not to outpace grades in downstream such as running a bunch of gas stations.

It's also getting more difficult to accomplish task with increasing process to control the range of ways of doing things.  This is good and bad.  BP drills very few exploration wells per year (10 wildcats).

pros: A well run, global company with resources and global reach leading to do some really exciting, challenging and pioneering stuff to work on. Looks after its people and provides a great range of benefits to match. A good work environment and typically modern offices. Skills and Leadership development has typically been OTJ recently but more resources are now available on-line. Strong values and ethics. A lot of opportunity in the digitization and automation space going forward.
cons: Like most Companies, the quality of your team leader will determine how you feel (i.e. supported, recognised, shared context etc.)  Industry has been going through a lot of reductions in waves on the back of lower hydro carbon prices with a drive towards simplifying and making more efficient. Hopefully should be turning the corner

pros: Pay, bonus, benefits, coworkers, overall culture and mindset
cons: Big global company that at times is too top heavy to make decisions. Can be a large disconnect between local business units central teams (people in London and Houston don’t always know how oil and gas production works and the ramifications and effort it takes to deliver what is asked). Also BP likes to change, saying around here goes “if you don’t like something, wait two years, it’ll change.” Can’t learn from mistakes, constantly changing systems to new systems that don’t work properly, unsupported and don’t meet requirements. Have now started rolling out new enterprise systems that don’t work properly for weeks after launch and with no actual training on how they work. Employees are expected to just figure it for themselves. Lots debt and expenses from oil spill, oil price downturn and buying assets has led them to sell current assets.

review_title: Good company to work for with above average compensation.
pros:
Above average pay very good benefits including pension plan and 7% matching on your 401k
Positive work environment
Good opportunities for development
Global company with travel opportunities
Stock plans for senior level managers
cons:
Management wants people with 20+ years of experience, so opportunities for younger people are limited
Heavy workload with little resources
Poor work life balance
Very political
Difficult to move across functions, once you start in a function that is where you will develop your career.
People are promoted on experience, not performance.
BP believes that you should move one level down to come work for BP because their people are so talented. The truth is that their people are the same as any other company, but they are likely to sell you into a lower position when you join the company.

review_title: Horrible culture, individuals don't live the values, managers lack vision and leadership
job_title: IT Project Manager in London, England
pros: Salary and benefits were OK for me.
cons: Culture of fear, unable to really speak your mind or challenge the status quo - must toe the party line or say goodbye to any ideas of career progression.  Managers are not leaders and have no vision or desire to change / improve ways of working.  Values would be great but managers do not live them!  Roles and responsibilities unclear, resulting in individuals duplicating / omitting tasks and conflict between team members.  Organisation is overly complex - much simplification and cost cutting (getting rid of 'dead wood') could be made, but won't happen due to above points.  Empire building and old boys network thrive, not many women here and if your face doesn't fit, you won't progress.  Office is a zombie zone - nobody talks to each other.  This is the most hostile, unfriendly work place I've ever encountered.

review_title: Great compensation & benefits, limited professional options
pros: BP, like many oil majors, has a very generous compensation and benefits package.  Salaries are very high compared to service companies, with bonuses when commodity prices are high.  Office physical environment is very nice (Fortune 100), and this large company has a large employee base from which one can learn from.
cons: Politics and lack of career opportunities given current and past legal problems.  Internally, the company is fractious and management undisciplined.  Specifically, many company rules are followed/voided by simple fiat.  Lack of management accountability has led to overemphasis on short-term gains above all else.

review_title: There are plusses and minuses to working at BP.
pros: BP has some great strategic thinkers who will keep the business a competitive supermajor for a long time.  In general, it makes good decisions on a global scale, and has some of the best technology in the industry.  It allows for flexible work hours and it truly does try to provide for a balance between personal and work life.
cons: There are the management elites, and then there are the grunts.  Shoving long-time employees into cubicles where there is not enough space to effectively work was just plain stupid.  The company spends a huge amount of effort on "Diversity and Inclusion", which is fine if you think the work environment has anything to do with "coming out of the closet", but everybody except the white male is celebrated.  It gets old.

review_title: Lots of interesting work but VERY bureaucratic
job_title: Senior Manager of Change Management in Naperville, IL
pros:
- A lot of opportunity to gain experience in different countries
- Very focused on providing a good employment package
- Able to work on cutting edge technology and new interesting processes
- Very smart people that work there
cons:
- Management style is very 1900's.  It is very hierarchical.  It was the first and only place where I heard a statement like - "When you talk to someone at my level"
- Managers are not well trained.  They are trained in BP procedures, not how to lead people
- Communication to employees is awful.  
- There is a false focus on safety.  At every meeting there was a "safety moment", but it was almost used as a way to avoid dealing with real issues

review_title: BP is a great place to be in, but Supply Chain isn't at par with its peers
pros:
Pay is good
Benefits are good
Alternate work schedule is great
Many good people to work with
cons:
Incompetent leadership within supply chain
Promotion is based on "who you know NOT what you know"
Supply Chain is one grade above premitive
Poor planning and poor execution
It is worse than congress when it comes to working together and executing plans 
Hiring people, warm boddies, just to fill positions
Unfair pay practiices even within people within the same grade level

pros: Good people for the most part. Large company with many opportunities to learn and grow
cons: Access to those opportunities. Select few are given roles and positions based on assumed skill sets while the majority are expected to have demonstrated skills and competencies. This provides a gap between people who actually know the job and could be great contributors or decision makers and those who are in management/leadership roles and don't know what is happening in the business

pros: Potential for good work / life balance. Depending on senior and middle management, BP has the facilities to create a work environment that is healthy and which allows individuals to grow, add value to the business and progress their careers.
cons: Large company bureaucracy can make affecting change cumbersome. Senior management can become out-of-touch with the real life issues on the "front". This requires a strong middle management layer to defend the business requirements and motivate their employees to ensure that over-arching strategies are not counterproductive.

pros: A  person early in their career may do well to exploit BP's passion for hiring them as relatively cheap labor.  They could jump ship in a few or if they want to be a bureaucrat they could be happy staying.  There can be work-life balance in some areas, and there are a few pockets of interesting work.
cons: It is uninspiring and bureaucratic.  Good things happen reluctantly.  There is no investment, growth or innovation in people or processes.  Impossible for serious people to reach their potential.  Hollow rhetoric abounds.    There was a widely held internal opinion that no company was more excellent than BP and amazingly managers are still acting like they believe that.

job_title: Operations Support Team Lead in Hallsville, TX
pros: Great pay and benefits and people
cons: Mid-level management is too busy trying to seem relative in order to save their jobs during all of the L48 reorganization process. They will even derail careers in order to achieve their own personal goals. Although, I've been gone for over a year the VPs of the L48 assets ARE irrelevant and too busy micromanaging instead of actually doing something worthwhile.

review_title: Great career path for chemical engineers
pros: Great benefits, including insurance, pension, high match on 401(k), matching charitable donations.  Salary lower than competitors but total package is competitive.  Wide array of job and career options, especially for those with chemical engineering backgrounds (arguably the core discipline especially in the downstream side of the business).  More freedom than some of its competitors who centrally dictate many of the decisions.  Largely self-directed career planning.
cons: Oftentimes the centrally run initiatives and programs lack foresight and effectiveness.  Managers often speak of simplification but very few of them will stand up to their superiors when push comes to shove and push back against senseless work.  While it can be great as an engineer to have ample opportunities at all levels of management, engineers aren't always the most charismatic leaders and the culture reflects that.

pros:
Great benefits and great colleagues to work with.  Lots of very capable and skilled people.

Several places to eat on site and sports facilities.
cons:
Technology Leadership is poor and there seems no understanding or what is happening in their areas...   

There has been a constant revisiting of business cases - as might be expected with $50 oil.  However, many original business cases contained no economic stress assessments or ROIs.   

All too often people forget which numbers they have provided to senior management and more time is spend on 'polishing' PPT and making sure that there is a 'credible' story for the multitude of different figures....

Also, so many people think they can do project management, yet in reality few have experience in this area.

pros: In my experiernce, BP employs truly quality people. I spent a summer there as an intern and was impressed with most of their employees. I worked as in intern within their supply chain department, and they gave me exposure to management at all structures and sought to give me a true view of the company while I was there.
cons: They are a bit more old-school. There are definitely some 'gotchas' in their culture indicative that they don't have a full theory of the relationship between employee and employer. There are also rather rigid evaluation and promotion practices that seemed detriment. And there are definitely people there counting down the days until retirement, even people in their 30s. They also don't do a very good job of empowering employees. They are afraid of developing single points of failure and will intentionally limit what you are working on. The place moves at a crawl at times.

job_title: Senior Level Leader in Naperville, IL
pros:
-The benefits 
-Facilities in Houston
-There are some really good people doing the work, but the folks making the calls at the top ruin it all around.
cons:
- Integrity is a joke. One of the most corrupt companies on earth.
- Profits before doing the right thing, each and every time. 
- Toxic environment all around. It's all about money no matter what the corporate governance says about the " BP Values". Do not believe it. They will use and abuse you and let you go before having to truly award you for getting after it and working hard to make a difference. They just don't care.

review_title: Like other big companies - BP is a huge bureaucracy. However, BP lacks strategic direction and full of inept leaders.
pros: Great company for work/life balance
cons: Hallmark of cronyism and nepotism if one is looking for career progression. Lots of processes, assurance, guidance  that does not add value but increases more people, meetings, and costs, that gets in the way of getting things done.

review_title: Management doesn't care  about anything, all politics
job_title: Research Associate in San Diego, CA
pros:
Large company
Good retirement benefit
Recent years try to increase number of female in leadership roles.
Lavish spending on office equipments and ergonomic analysis.
cons:
Company has local rules governed by local HR.. Very unclear and poor local HR. No definite rules/handbook to follow. 1800 HR (BPpeople) support line is useless.
Relative expensive healthcare plan and very few PTO days for industry standard.
Managers do not care about employees' feedback. 
Poor mid and upper level management on local site.
Spend excessive amount of time on trainings regarding BP core values.
Encourage "open doors" culture but not true at all....
Tolerate employees with poor performance and do not reward high performance employees.
Do not fairly promote employees.
Difficult to climb up career ladder until move around to various BP locations worldwide.

review_title: BP - exceptionally intelligent people working in a less than effective environement
job_title: Senior Change Management Manager in Naperville, IL
pros:
*Great pay and benefits, really unrivaled for the amount of work.
* A lot of focus on work/life balance
* Ability to take on projects and learn easily
* Huge opportunities if you are willing to take them
cons:
* Little internal communication that makes sense.  Senior management seems lost
* Poor management at the mid level.  They have little training
* Crazy structure.  One manager managing two other managers who manage one person each
* So much overlap in the organization that there is too much double work
* Did I say too much overlap?

job_title: Petroleum Systems Analyst in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: Great overseas opportunities; work/life balance is awesome, very flexible, there is more interest in whether you get your job done but not necessarily where you do it; professionally I have had great opportunity for growth in my discipline.
cons: In the past HR has seemingly viewed the employee as the enemy rather than someone to support. This seems to be changing with the new organization so we are hopeful. Bad external press and low base pay caused low employee morale in the past. Recent moves to rectify base pay off cycle are very encouraging now.  Company is very performance-based so beware if you don't deliver! Although location is quite flexible (e.g. if you need to stay home for any reason), it is expected you will do your job so be prepared for some weekend and night work.

review_title: I would recommend BP as a place to work
pros:
BP is a good place to work with a strong commitment to fairness, diversity and ethical conduct.
BP offers plenty of opportunity for professional development.
Senior management are generally of a very high calibre.
cons:
BP is prone to constant reorganisation, management changes causing a loss of focus, continuity and delivery.  This makes it an unstable work environment.
There is little respect for work life balance and no consideration for the impact on individuals when determining new tasks or initiatives.
The diversity agenda has a significant influence on HR-related decisions and will often have greater importance than merit.

review_title: Great place to work , but shrinking/sinking ship on the downstream side.
pros: BP employs some very smart people. The culture is laid back with plenty of flexible working arrangements available. There are some great people that try to work common objectives.
cons: The company is risk adverse.  After the Texas City and Gulf disasters, there is no appetite to operate assets due to risk exposure.  The downstream business is little more than a shell of what it used to be.  The company's downsized structure means there really aren't any opportunities to grow. All downstream businesses are restructuring with substantial layoffs ahead for 2015. The company will most likely divest and exit the downstream business when the dust clears.

pros: BP treats their people really well. They have lots of benefits that exceed the standard level of benefits in the US. They are a flexible workplace. Seem to be more liberal than a lot of other companies in the industry.
cons: While I very much respect and approve of the executive-level leaders of the company, I've had experience with poor management on the lower team lead/manager levels. Myself and many other colleagues are not necessarily happy in their roles. I'm not sure if it's the stress level or the environment, but there can be quite a bit of unrest. Very slow progression up the career ladder. Poor training for more junior employees since classes were cut from the budget.

pros: The work is interesting although can be transactional
cons:
There is very high turnover. Many of LSC staff are contractors so the high turnover may not be visible internally to HR. 

BP is known for supporting work life balance. The LSC has set working conditions created by the leadership team that are very different to the rest of BP.  The work life balance is poor. 

BP offers flexible working but at the LSC employees are not permitted flexible working  (very strict working hours of 9-5) or to work from home. Some of the leadership team do work from home. 

Better when busy is a LSC value that should be better when efficient. 

There are lots of unnecessary processes and trackers that don't add value. Resource is poorly managed. 

I would not recommend working here. Most people would be accustomed to a more forward thinking flexible workplace.

review_title: Subsea and Floating Systems Graduate Engineer
job_title: Subsea and Floating Systems Graduate Engineer in Sunbury, England
pros: Excellent pay and benefits and working hour arrangement. Every other Friday is a day off as well. There is a huge investment (circa £100k/graduate) in training over the 3 year program. You will be training to become an excellent project manager if you join the Subsea Engineering Grad scheme.
cons: It is impossible to become a chartered engineer without a secondment to service company where detailed engineering work takes place. It is not possible to develop skills in engineering other than a high level understanding of how equipment works and project management.

pros: Great benefits and reasonable salaries. Worked with some good people over the years and are as close as family. The work environment outside Houston was genuine.
cons: Younger management in key roles with no management or people experience. BP used to be a mature company with great values but has given way to inexperience and management tactics that now discourage speaking up and sharing concerns. If you're not in agreement with management, you're potentially a target for termination. Strongly considering my future with this company. The falling price of oil has really shown me BP's true colors. Not a pretty sight.

review_title: Very good if you always step up and ask for responsibility, then can be very dissapointing after a while
pros:
stable company
excellent work life balance
genuine care for employees
can be a very good place to learn, if you always seek it
cons:
your career path totally depend on your current manager, if you are good and step up for accountability, you'll go up, but if your manager is not a leader, you'll be burried, systems are there but your manager is the most important thing
too many frequent changes in the company structure, without leaving enough time for a scheme to prove it self
too much dependency on consultants, no trust in their own employees to deliver alone

pros: The biggest highlight is everyone is respectful to each another and embraces diversity. BP is a company that stands by its values and belief (Safety, Respect, Excellence, Courage and One Team), making sure every employee is well-informed and practises them. In addition, BP is puts strong emphasis on innovation. A lot of learning opportunities to get hold of the state-of-the-art technology for engineering role. Working as an intern in BP is rewarding, you are allowed to take part in various activities be it technical or social within the company.
cons: The application process is rigorous and sometimes a bit overwhelming. However, this is pretty standard for any oil and gas companies. Make sure you read about the company values and show your genuine side. And you will do fine!

review_title: BP Good at Acquisaitions and Terrible at Operations
pros: It is a place holder job.  Since they took over Amoco and ARCO they have taken on the philosophy of burning through employees and then discarding them - just like Pepsi in the 1990's.
cons: If you are not BP heritage or a Brit, your upward mobility is severely limited.  It is especially limited if you are ARCO heratige.

review_title: Working at BP isn't so bad, but the pay isn't enough to live on if you're on your own.
pros: Usually there is down-time through out your day which helps if you need to study for school. My boss is great. She's very understanding and always willing to give me the days off that I need.
cons: Making minimum wage isn't enough, especially if you live on your own and have students loans to pay. Sometimes the customers are a little difficult to deal with and that can be stressful.

job_title: Future Leader Programmer in London, England
pros: Great opportunity to join the company at an entry level leadership position, It provided me with a deep and broad understanding and knowledge of the industry and  the company in a relative short time thanks to the access to peoples and resources that the FLP community provide, great exposure and visibility to senior leadership level enabled by the wide and diverse source of the community which spanned worldwide across the downstream business. I'm really impressed with the focus and attention that the company provide to work-life balance for each employee.
cons: sometime decisions making can be too long and cause of delays, difficult to navigate the large number of processes available

review_title: Great company yet financially taking a hit from the GOM spill
pros: Very good formal training for engineers.  Good internship program.  Very rigorous and good development program for graduates.  Excellent work life balance.  Highly competitive work amongst co-workers yet the working culture takes the stress out.
cons:
Uncompetitive bonus against other companies in the industry.  Perhaps this is due to its uncertain financials resulting from the spill.
Poor knowledge management system. Finding  information is like looking for a needle in a haystack unless you are used to it.
Process process process...it is highly complex and can stress someone out.  It's complex process can become its own downfall.
Not an encouraging company for mid level employees, too much emphasis on graduates and interns.

pros:
A real commitment to being a leader in future energy provision
Values and behaviours that everyone knows and commits to
Opportunity to work with some really smart people across the world
Variety of careers and career paths
cons:
Due to size and complexity can sometimes be difficult to drive global standardisation in areas that don’t need to be different. Results in duplication of effort and multiple ways of doing things. 
Feels a little bit old school at times 
Decision making can take a long time, too many people want a say in every decision. Decision approvals often held very high and leaders not trusted to take lower risk decisions

review_title: Some good things and some less than good things.
pros: This is a true global organization.  Everyday, you would tell that the culture reflects the diversity of its workforce.  There are some really smart people here.  Also, the focus on safety and doing things the right way is a testament to the organizational learning after the Gulf of Mexico incident.
cons: It's surprising that they don't do a better job managing people.  There are more average employees than you would expect at a company of this calibre.  I could never tell if it was because certain managers/leaders ignored it, had no way of seeing it clearly, or were themselves mediocre.  The end result was that there were employees who thought they were much better than they really were.

review_title: Nice manager but bad sales equipment
pros:
Most customers are nice
Lucky to have a really nice manager (who over worked her self to be honest)
Free coffee
cons:
Eftpos terminal would regularly stuff up and BP would not replace them with a new brand even though they were a big inconvenience to customers. Lead to long lines unnecessarily , and a few customers even walking away without paying. Furthermore everytimr there was an IT upgrade there would always be more bugs in the system. 

Also the "10%" discount on shop items was ridiculous : you can't apply it to promotional items or fuel. Always shopped at a coles/Woolworths close by before starting my shift.

Poor career progression. Have only worked here for 10months, but my colleagues who have worked here for more than 4 years were rejected the opportunity to progress to an assistant manager position despite knowing the store and customers the best!

review_title: A great place to get experience, but not a great place to build a career.
job_title: Division Order Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: BP will challenge you to grow professionally and will invest in you by extensive training for young professionals.  BP executive leadership has improved significantly in its communication with the entire company about the direction of the company and how it will impact the various areas of the company.
cons: The Land Department is a functional work environment.  "When they hire you to do a job in Land, they expect you to do if it for a very long time." - Sr. Land Leadership  There isn't much room for growth in Land and you will not be able to transfer to other jobs outside of Land.

pros: Good salary and benefits. Opportunities for professional-grade staff to move around the company and work abroad, although you have to be very proactive in managing your own career. Work/life balance in head office much improved since the departure of workaholic execs like John Browne.
cons: Constant organisational change, which can be very draining. In nearly 20 years with the company I have seen 3 major rounds of layoffs plus numerous smaller re-organisations. It’s a boom and bust business because of dependence on the oil price and we are currently in a bust phase. There’s a concentration on cost-cutting, perks are disappearing and the company is shrinking. It feels like people are jumping ship and BP’s poor safety record makes it vulnerable to takeovers. Advancement is still too dependent on personal networks, although this is improving with a more transparent internal job posting/application system. Few development opportunities for admin/support staff.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Gold Coast
pros: Bad management. No team work or incentives. Be prepared to pick up others slack. Expect to be pushed into selling extras to customers. No higher management concern of staff or reward for hard work or loyalty. Break their rules or make mistakes its rewarded not by retraining but less shifts.
cons: No incentive to try for promotion and they pretty much employ people allready skilled in higher management jobs rather than train from within. No perks to job. Safety issues, and lack of decent pay to commensurate phsysical labour, late shifts or early early starts. Expect the world of you with  no acknowledgement.

review_title: Great place to work, fast paced, lots of challenges
pros:
I worked at the Business Service Center in Budapest, Hungary for 4 years. Overall, it was a great experience, with lots of pros and very few cons.
- Fast paced, challenging environment
- Lots of opportunities to learn and develop professionally
- Opportunities to move internally
- Great team and stakeholders
- Continuous Improvement is part of the culture
- Agile working opportunities
cons:
Salaries at the BSC are low in comparison to the rest of BP. Salaries are not always competitive in comparison to other shared service centers in Budapest, either. 
Unclear rules about promotions
Salary caps when promoted internally
Some unprofessional and unethical managers
Benefit package could be more competitive

pros: The salary is good. The advance training your recieve is excellent. The insurance is good as is the medical care
cons: no time off to live a personal life, days off often cancelled , vacation non-existant, work days 18 hours, no personal communication allowed while on ship. your not allowed personal computer communication or phone calls while on the ship. The days working and days off schedual is ignored. I haven't been off the payroll ship in the gulf  except for training, doctors appoinments and a few other short assignments in 18 plus  months.

pros: Great people, interesting work, opportunity for international postings, good access to training opportunities, pay and bonuses fair, other benefits quite good, many of the managers are top notch.
cons: Decisions made elsewhere without understanding local situation, typical 'red tape' and process of an international company, expect extra hours when approaching deadlines adding more scope when you meet all agreed requirements, excessive levels of assurance of technical work.

review_title: Great benefits, competitive compensation, personal development valued, but riddle with corporate complexity
pros: Good health benefits with low premiums. 401k matching up to 7%. Salary and bonus compensation is competitive and in line with market. 9-80 schedule is a huge perk. Work life balance is good, but will vary depending on your role. There was a focus on personal career development when oil prices were high, but the focus on that has lightened in the recent oil price environment.
cons: It can be a frustrating place to work if you care about doing meaningful work and impacting the bottom line. The company is riddled with workflow complexity, tons of process, and indecisive middle management.

pros: BP provides a safe and friendly culture due to their values and behaviors and code of conduct.   Ability to network with different levels of the organization from peers to senior leaders of the organization.    Pays well with good benefits.
cons: There are high expectations for high performers and different level for low performers to which both employees are hired in at the same level.   if you are a high performer, you are expected to deliver at that level so  you end up still delivering expectations although you exceeds the low performer at the same level as you.   Also, they could improve on the career development of employees especially those who are experienced hires.

pros:
- Never need to work late (blessing and a curse)
- Great pay for few hours but slow pay progression after initial high rate.
cons:
Outdated organisation. Finance function is at least 10 years behind in terms of process management and software solutions. Results in high paid staff doing menial tasks such as data entry and management. 

Low morale and poor management.  Line managers tend to have poor management skills and don't know how to get best out of their team. So focused on getting the job done that innovation is killed.

BP staff members will think of 100 reasons not to do something. No innovation, complete aversion to change. Middle management scared of how innovation will likely make many of their jobs redundant and expose inefficiency.

review_title: Pretty decent retailer to work for
pros:
Flexibility with shifts
Varied day to day jobs to keep you busy and intrested
Meal discount on 6 and more hours
Standard 15% disc
Good training system
Some job opportunities for supervisor roles
cons:
Management heavy per store
Removal of paid breaks in the pipeline but no new benefits/increase pay to equal it out
Don't respect paid by the hour.... Not by the jobs to done per shift
Night-shift pay is crap, no single person increase
Will always be looking for staff to cover at short notice and they will call you repeatedly!
Difficult to find transferable skills even with retail in general

review_title: BP - from a recent college grad's POV
pros: BP really stresses work, life balance.  Employees have to be here at core hours, but other than that, you can get here earlier and leave earlier.  Also, 9/80 is great because you get every other Friday off.  I also like the managed 3 year challenge program.  It gives a college grad really useful information to get a head start here in this huge company.
cons: Sometimes it takes too long for a project to be done because of the size of the company.  Also the training program is not the most put together one.  A challenger really has to keep track of everything to be sure that his or her training is on track.  BP's size sometimes would make you feel that you are just a number in the crowd.

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Northampton, England
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed my 4 years working at BP Connect Marks & Spencer. Good work/ life balance, good training, welfare of employees always at the forefront, great management for the most part, and a relaxed/ understanding/ flexible work culture. I think most employees stay for a very long time, or hardly any time at all - as it’s not for everyone. For me - it was one of the most positive working experiences and would highly recommend to anyone whether they are looking for something temporary or somewhere to grow and progress, as there is a very clear and structured route to progression within the company. You also have job security with a large company such as BP.
cons: Difficult to get the recognition to progress, and unsociable working hours.

review_title: Get in where you fit in.
pros: Good growth overall.  Corporate structure and innovation is nice too.  Management does take time to listen to ideas but it can be a lengthy process to get anything changed due to the large nature of the company.
cons: Very demanding organization.  You get out of it what you put in.  BP demands a lot from their employees overall and is not a family oriented type of atmosphere if you're into that sort of thing.  Sometimes they seem to hire a lot of young and less experienced individuals and I have had to spent countless amounts of time training them.  Not enough experience in the workplace.

review_title: Really good people but poor leadership and not the company it used to be.
pros: Salary and benefits and many good legacy people from Amoco, ARCO and Sohio
cons: Leadership thinks they know leadership but are not effective.  Reinforce this by promoting those like themselves - mainly engineers.  Corporate culture fosters and protects "Group Leaders" that play in their own circles and draw large salaries and benefits while at the same time asking for cost reductions from everyone else.  They are milking the business for their benefit vs. putting their employees as a primary focus.  Great acquisition target in the US for Refining and Marketing businesses.  Struggling to find its role and continuing to shrink as the corporation sells pieces for cash.

review_title: Tale of two companies, great and terrible all at the same time
pros:
- Awesome pay
- Awesome benefits
- Fascinating work (at times)
- Complex and interesting learning
- Huge global experience
cons:
- Bipolar management, they talk about safety on the surface, but only really care about the bottom line
- Very political
- The span of control of many managers is extremely small. This makes decisions difficult to make and everything moves very slowly
- Lots of work on making things look good versus doing great work
- So many meaningless meetings.  It's nearly impossible to get anything done with all of them.

pros:
Management good at being flexible with rota
50% of on-shift food (at BP/M&S store)
Monthly online training is good to keep up to date with business
Can earn Love2Shop / M&S / Tesco / Sainsbury's and more gift cards
Store does charity events and dress up at christmas time 
Friendly staff and customers
cons:
Unsociable shifts: 6AM-2PM, 2PM-10PM (night shift 10PM-6AM)
Night shift should get paid way more than they do, do same amount of work (if not more) but with less staff and having to put up with Friday night / Saturday night customers
More often than not understaffed

pros: Good pay, room for job growth,  open 24/7 so possibility of working any section of the day you prefer. Room to grow in your career and potentially learn new skills. Free coffee, staff discount.
cons: If you're not full time with a set roster you can be rostered at all different times of the day, it burns you out. Lots of heavy lifting, generally there will be a Jack of all trades position, I regularly would be put in this role other than console operator, you have to move a lot of cartons of drinks and other heavy products.

review_title: Great to employees, but needs to shed off excess bureaucratic weight.
pros:
Every other friday off
Free lunch
Great colleagues
Nice management
The Share scheme and pension plan
Emphasis on work life balance
Being able to take time off whenever you want as long as you get the work done. 
Really friendly people who will take the time to help and support you when you need it. 
A large organisation means that you'll always find someone who has good advice on the work that you're doing.
cons:
Bureaucracy (they are working on this but we'll see if it works out) 
Over analysis of issues instead of just going and doing it!

review_title: Not particularly dynamic, but great training and worldwide opportunities
pros: You get to work on projects with real scale, e.g, Rumalia, Iraq and Azerbaijan - that are not available outside the supermajors (Shell, Exxon etc).  People are willing to teach / mentor junior staff, and the work / life balance is excellent.  Pay is okay but not as good as small oil companies.
cons: It takes a long while to get anywhere, with little opportunity for rapid progression.  To get on you've probably got to spend some time working in some fairly unpleasant places.  In recent years you get lot less control over what type of jobs you want to do than you did, say, 5 years ago.

review_title: Great place to sit around until you retire, but if you want the going rate then look elsewhere.
job_title: Operator in Kingston upon Hull, England
pros: Great Pension (if you joined before 2010) and er... I'll get back to you.
cons: Promotions take for ever and they have little faith in throwing people into a job and letting them sink or swim. They would rather send you on patronizing "development" courses for 10 years before offering you a secondment in the next role "up." They are not the best payers, in fact for some job titles they are the worst in the local area, and they think that offering a cycle to work scheme is able to offset this.

job_title: Former Senior Level F Leader (Retired) in Houston, TX
pros: BP represents a classic example of a 'top down' organization.  If you are wanting to learn about complex organizations and how they operate, this is the place to work.
cons: My colleagues and I used to discuss the analogy of the "Emperor's New Clothes" to BP.  Management likes to make major organizational changes every 2-3 years.  This includes reshuffling of personnel, now policies, practices and procedures as well as new business processes.  The result is an organization that is always in flux and one where senior level leadership prescribes the changes based on studies/consultants without input from the organization...especially operations.
